Massachusetts General Laws, ch. 208, \u0.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to the Massachusetts General Laws, ch. 208, § 28, which grants the Probate and Family Court the authority to modify custody orders when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of a minor child.

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, the Court may modify custody or visitation orders when a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the best interests of the child.

**D.C. v. J.S., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1112 (.proposition: A parent’s relocation, which significantly alters the feasibility of an existing parenting schedule, constitutes a material change in circumstances.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..proposition: The physical and emotional well-being of the child is paramount in determining custody and parenting schedules.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames both custody and removal questions in terms of the "best interests of the child" and identifies the effect on the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs as "most important." It explains that while the custodial parent’s interests matter, they are relevant only insofar as they bear on the child’s quality of life, confirming that the child’s well-being is paramount in custody-related determinations.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.

**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.proposition: The physical and emotional well-being of the child is paramount in determining custody and parenting schedules.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames the removal and custody analysis in terms of the children’s “best interests,” explicitly defined as grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the child, and it evaluates factors such as schooling, special needs, emotional impact of parental conflict, and stability. The opinion also ties joint custody and relocation decisions to promoting the children’s welfare and development, demonstrating that the children’s physical, educational, and emotional well-being are paramount in determining whether a parenting arrangement (including relocation) will be approved. Although the case is about relocation with joint custody, the articulated standard directly reflects that the child’s well-being is the controlling consideration in custody/parenting schedule decisions.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.relevant_excerpt: “‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’ … It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts… whether … removal is in a child’s best interests.”

**R.A. v. G.P., 89 Mass. App. Ct. 1135 (.proposition: The best interests of the child standard includes considerations of the child’s routine, education, and overall stability.

**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 600.proposition: The best interests of the child standard includes considerations of the child’s routine, education, and overall stability.
**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 600.support_reasoning: The opinion centers on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence in best‑interests determinations, but in doing so it repeatedly notes factors such as the child’s school performance, the father’s involvement with the child’s education and activities, and the existing caregiving arrangement. Those are routine, educational, and stability-related considerations folded into the best‑interests analysis. However, the case is more directly about domestic violence than about defining best‑interests generally, so its support is indirect rather than explicit.
**Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 600.relevant_excerpt:
The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers. Finally, the Probate Court judge noted that the father, who had been a heavy drinker, had not used alcohol since 1985 and attends weekly sessions of Alcoholics Anonymous. The court also mandated that both parents should remain in therapy.
...
As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim.

**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts routinely recognize that excessively burdensome commutes and disrupted sleep schedules are not in the best interests of the child.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on relocation and custody modification standards under Massachusetts law, not on commute burdens or sleep schedules. While it mentions that a one-hour each-way drive between Providence and Massachusetts is not an unreasonable burden and can be done with “relative ease,” it does not characterize such commuting or related schedule disruptions as contrary to a child’s best interests, nor does it discuss sleep schedules as a factor. Thus, it does not establish the broader proposition that courts routinely recognize excessively burdensome commutes and disrupted sleep as not in a child’s best interests.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Finding no. 55: ‘The Court finds that the Mother can continue to drive to Massachusetts to pick up the minor child for her parenting time with relative ease. The Mother has managed to travel for eight (8) years back and forth from Massachusetts to Rhode Island… The travel time of one hour each way is not unreasonable under the current custody schedule.’”

**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (2.proposition: The child’s ability to maintain consistent and positive educational performance is a critical factor in determining best interests.
**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best-interests standard in custody determinations, emphasizing stability, continuity with the primary caregiver, and parents’ abilities to attend to the child’s medical, daily, and general welfare needs. While it briefly notes that the mother is more attuned to Kali’s “educational” needs, it does not identify the child’s consistent or positive educational performance as a critical or distinct factor in the best‑interests analysis. Education is mentioned only incidentally among many considerations, not elevated to the specific, critical status asserted in the proposition.
**Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 841 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Ultimately, the judge concluded that the mother was more ‘attuned to [Kali’s] medical, educational, and daily needs’ and this tipped the balance as to where the best interests of the child lay.” (Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 847).

**Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546.proposition: The circumstances of this case closely align with those in **Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546 (2010)**, wherein the Court rejected visitation arrangements that imposed undue burdens on the child’s education and stability.
**Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546.support_reasoning: The concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the lack of authority to order the mother and child back to Massachusetts after a lawful relocation. While it criticizes disruption to the child’s stability and emphasizes the need to fashion reasonable long‑distance visitation, it does not involve or reject any specific visitation arrangement on the ground that it imposed undue burdens on the child’s education or stability. Thus, the case does not stand for the specific proposition described, even if its general concern for stability is consistent with it.
**Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546.relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother's decision to relocate. ... Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child."
